text: [Ethan] Yesterday our country was sold out to the highest bidder by our senators.
And I usually don't make videos like this because I don't like getting involved in politics,
I don't like dividing our fanbase between
Republicans and Democrats, and everyone else.
But this, to me, is one of the most unpartisan issues that I've ever come across.
If you are a Republican, if you're a Democrat, whatever you are in between,
this story, this appeal, affects you negatively.
This bill passed the Senate floor yesterday.
They repealed a protection called
"Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services."
Now this bill was put in place to prevent ISPs,
(Internet Service Providers),
from selling our browsing history to the highest bidder.
That includes: anyone you've spoken to; websites you've been on; apps that you've downloaded;
pretty much anything you do online, with this bill being repealed,
is for sale!
It may not be such a big deal to you, you're like
"What? Who cares about what porn I watch?"
It's a slippery slope, guys.
If you hold public office,
which apparently these old fucks don't realize
that they're about to get blackmailed by repealing this bill.
If you're a public figure, if you're anybody,
your browsing history can be used to blackmail you; it can be used to smear you,
and it's just a slippery slope to the long road of completely repealing net-neutrality.
If you're not American, you'll be like "Oh, this doesn't affect me."
It does affect you, dude, because all of this shit permeates to the rest of the world.
The UK, just like a few months ago, passed a similar bill, okay?
But here's the best part about that bill:
the Congress who passed it made an exemption to themselves.
So they're like: "You can spy on the citizens, that's fine, but you can't spy on us.
We don't care, as long as we don't get spied on."
As if these companies aren't making enough money,
they're already charging us gouging prices for shitty Internet...
Like, compared to the rest of the world,
America has some of the slowest Internet, okay?
And they're charging us even more than other countries pay.
They're already allowed to serve us ads based on our browsing history!
Do we really need to give them a third option to make money
by completely whoring out our privacy to anyone who wants to buy it?!
Why are we catering to them, trying to make them more money
at the compromise of our own fucking welfare?
The question I have when I see something like this is just:
Why?
Why are you doing this? Why are you bothering?
Why are you wasting your time to introduce legislation
that hurts everybody across the board,
so that AT&T and Comcast can make more money?
Why?

and here you can see how much money each of them has received
from these telecommunication companies.
